 for Evolutionary Computation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=211599040; y=-y1Ei-qWKVcKwQDM-kSVqzCp9ny1u6oK8OjPiL8ct-d6LMYb3pig
X-Yahoo-Profile: jeffreyclune

Hello-

> OK, I thought that, in Hyperneat, links with near-zero weights were
> removed. In your case, FT-NEAT can change these near-zero links and
> give them back a significant value (if it's useful).

I see what you are saying. You are right that topology is being evolved to
some extent because one can think of links with a weight of zero as being
absent. You are also right that in the HybrID implementation we tested in
the paper, FT-NEAT can change these values from 0 to another value
(functionally adding the link back in).

> Did you try to remove these near-zero weights before running FT-NEAT?
> It could improve the search of FT-NEAT by reducing the size of the
> search space (but some variations would become impossible).

We did not try that. It is an interesting suggestion.  But if the mutation
rate for FT-NEAT is low enough, presumably links will only be added back in
if they are helpful. But the optimal mutation rate for FT-NEAT might be high
enough that some unhelpful links are being added, at which point your
suggested method could improve performance. I guess we'd  have to try it out
to know for sure.

Thanks for the suggestion.

Cheers,
Jeff
